job_description: The Office of Chief Medical Examiner investigates cases of persons who die within New York City from criminal violence, by accident, by suicide, suddenly when in apparent health, when unattended by a physician, in a correctional facility or in any suspicious or unusual manner or where an application is made pursuant to law for a permit to cremate a body of a person.We exist to provide answers in support of families, victims and community during times of profound need.     The core values of the OCME are to put the mission of the agency first, to be truly dedicated and to have integrity in every aspect of our professional life. The Deputy Commissioner for Administration reports to the Executive Deputy Commissioner of Administration and Finance. The Deputy Commissioner is responsible for direction, oversight and coordination of multiple support departments including Human Resources, Procurement, Materials Management, Contracting and Facilities. The OCME is a facilities based organization with a number of laboratories and morgues. The oversight of all facilities is the responsibility of the Deputy Commissioner.  The primary function of this position is to support Agency program operations and ensure that human capital resources, contracts, facilities and other resources are managed effectively in pursuit of agency goals and our public mandate.  The incumbent ensures that the Agency complies with all City, State and Federal guidelines for procurement, contracting and building reporting and is very knowledgeable with the Cityâ€™s budgeting process. The Deputy Commissioner for Administration has extensive experience and knowledge of how the City works and has an established network of city agencies including MOCS, the Comptrollers, and OMB. The Deputy Commissioner is an expert project manager, and able to oversee multiple and complex projects and interacts with other NYC agencies in a fast-paced, pressure-filled environment.    Duties will include but are not limited to the following:    â€¢ The Deputy Commissioner provides  strategic and operational leadership to Procurement Department, inclusive of Contracts, Purchasing and Materials Management   â€¢ The D/C Supports the Executive D/C to provide advocacy within Mayoral agencies and City Council and to prepare testimony, including that for legislation affecting the OMCE.  â€¢ The D/C supports the Executive D/C to develop and execute agency capital projects including overseeing the design and construction  of new facilities   â€¢ The D/C is  responsible to ensure that all the laboratories and morgue facilities  are appropriately maintained and resourced with staff and materials and  in compliance with all City building codes   â€¢ The D/C will advise, support and collaborate with ACCO on agency initiatives for highly complex and/or long term projects  â€¢ Possess familiarity with Federal, State and local legislation in support of Citywide procurement practices;   â€¢ Knowledge of City guidelines for OTPS expenditures, reporting requirements, delegation of authority, process for vendor selection and responsibility;  â€¢ The D/C will advise, support and collaborate with the A/C of Human Resources to ensure that Personnel actions, policies and procedures comply with EEO, Civil Service and legislative requirements and mandates;  â€¢ Ensures coordination between administrative and fiscal/finance functions  â€¢ Coordinates with all programs and program managers/executives  â€¢ Other duties as assigned.

business_title: Energy Code Compliance Audit Program Senior Engineer
business_title_phonetic: Energy Code Compliance Audit Program Senior Engineer
job_description: GREENER and GREATER opportunities are GROWING at the Department of Buildings. The Department of Buildings has an essential role in the PlaNYC for a Greater Greener New York and One City- Built to Last citywide initiatives; we are charged with the primary responsibility for implementation of the Greater, Greener Buildings Plan, which is a suite of laws focused on energy efficiency in New York City buildings. A foundation of these initiatives is enforcement of the New York City Energy Conservation Code, since energy consumption in NYC buildings contributes nearly three-quarters of our greenhouse gas emissions.    What else is the Department of Buildings doing to promote sustainability?     The Department of Buildings has a number of other initiatives which currently includes: Buildings Sustainability Board, Green Roofs and Solar Property Tax Abatement programs, Green Codes Task Force, Sustainable Contractor Designation Program and CUNY Solar America Cities partnership.    JOIN THE SUSTAINABILITY TEAM!    Department of Buildings is currently looking for a Sustainability Enforcement Engineer for the DOB Sustainability Team. The selected candidate will report directly to the Director of Sustainability Enforcement.     The Sustainability Enforcement Engineer will be accountable for the following:    -Assisting the Director of Sustainability Enforcement to monitor quality control of Energy Code inspections;  -Manage a team of specialty inspectors pertaining to the New York City Energy Conservation Code, including inspections related to the Energy Conservation Code Progress Inspections (Form TR-8);  -Reading and reviewing design and/or equipment plans and specifications;  -Coordinating Enforcement initiated investigations and special projects involving monitoring, surveillance, research and analysis for the construction, alteration or repair of buildings under the jurisdiction of the Department of Buildings to note compliance with and violation of the Energy Code, Building Code, and other pertinent codes and regulations regarding structures, materials, applications, and methods of construction, etc.;  -Responding to public inquires on technical issues in person, via telephone, via fax and e-mails;  -Answer questions from the public regarding construction codes, referenced design standards, and related laws and rules;  -Tracking violations, stop work orders and summonses for non-compliance with the Energy Code and other applicable laws and preparing related reports;  -Participating in the creation and delivery of training and educational documentation to internal staff as well as to the public with respect to Energy Code and the installation of sustainable building solutions;  -Assisting other staff in the Office of Technical Affairs and Code Development as needed, including the Director of Energy Code Compliance and the Chief Sustainability Officer;  -Working efficiently, effectively and  creatively with minimal direction under aggressive deadlines; and,  -Communicating the Agencyâ€™s core mission and message to customers with the goal of improving public perception and clearly communicating initiatives.
minimum_qual_requirements: A valid New York State License as a Professional Engineer is required. In addition, candidates must have six (6) years of full-time paid experience in civil, mechanical, electrical, chemical or air pollution control engineering work, at least two (2) years of which shall have been as an administrative engineer.

job_description: Mayor de Blasio pledged to make NYC a â€œgreen city,â€ as well as a more equitable city.  NYC Environmental Protection (DEP), the nationâ€™s largest water utility is planning for that future.   DEP plans to expand green infrastructure with a growing group of partners, not only to manage stormwater, but also to improve water quality, address the growing impacts of climate change, and provide visible and usable public benefits.  DEP has committed to spend $1.8 billion for green infrastructure and intends to innovate and lead in this field, and help to advance equity in New York City.    	  Under the direction of the Senior Advisor to the Commissioner and in coordination with the Office of Green Infrastructure, the Special Assistant will assist in the direction of day to day operations, ensuring good communication; assist in the development and maintenance of formal policies and procedures and overall strategies to manage agency efforts to expand green infrastructure.  The selected candidate will also work closely with the Senior Advisor and other senior staff to expand green infrastructure partnerships in the nonprofit and private sector in New York City.  This work may include expanding collaboration with committed nonprofit partners like The Trust for Public Land, The Nature Conservancy, and New York Restoration Project, as well as smaller community-based organizations; and identifying and collaborating with effective private partners in affordable housing, property management, real estate development, and other businesses, trades, and industries.      The selected candidate will also assist in developing supportive budgeting analyses, legislation, regulations, and communication strategies and materials.    The Special Assistant will be required to help manage day-to-day issues and workflow, including the Senior Advisorâ€™s correspondence, meeting follow-up and regular information requests; monitor, troubleshoot and, in certain instances, directly manage priority projects. The Special Assistant will be responsible for the management of schedules, files and filing systems, and material support for the Senior Advisor.    ***Only Candidates permanent in the title Staff Analyst should apply***

job_description: The Nurse-Family Partnership (NFP) Program within the Bureau of Maternal, Infant and Reproductive Health is a nationally replicated nurse home visiting program that has been rigorously evaluated for over 30 years which has demonstrated significant improvements in pregnancy outcomes, parenting skills and family self-sufficiency. The NFP program began in NYC in 2003.  It is currently in all five boroughs and is the largest urban site in the nation.     DUTIES WILL INCLUDE BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO:     Under supervision of the NFP Jamaica-site Supervisor, the NFP Nurse Home Visitor will:    -- Perform the following duties:, Apply the nursing process to assess the six prescribed NFP domains, including physical, emotional, social and environmental needs of women and their families as they relate to health and life course development.    -- Assist women and their families in establishing realistic goals and measurable outcomes; utilize reflective practice, stages of change, and other behavioral change approaches.    -- Provide counseling to assist women & their families in attaining targeted goals in areas including prenatal & postpartum care, nutrition, parenting, childcare, family planning, special health problems, housing, continuing education & employment, Evaluate women's & families' progress toward target goals, revise plan of care as appropriate.    -- Develop a working relationship with women and their families that promotes trust and problem solving.    -- Assist client in developing supportive relationships with family members and friends during pregnancy, birth and childcare.    -- Link women and family with community resources that are relevant to their specific needs, Consult and collaborate with other professionals providing service to women and their families.    -- Record nursing activities in a timely manner and in accord with project visit and institutional guidelines.    --Participate in ongoing learning in program implementation, Meet with supervisor for minimum of one hour per week.    -- Participate in weekly 2-hour team meetings and case conferences, Perform other related duties as needed.

job_description: The Tax Incentive Programs unit administers a wide variety of tax abatement and exemption programs to facilitate private and publicly-subsidized rehabilitation and new construction programs throughout New York City.    420-c/Article XI Analyst  The 420-c and Article XI tax exemption programs are administered by HPD to help facilitate the construction and rehabilitation of affordable housing in New York City.  The 420-c program provides a full or partial exemption from real estate taxes to affordable housing that has been developed with low-income housing tax credits.  The Article XI program provides, upon the approval of both HPD and the City Council, a full or partial exemption to affordable housing owned by Housing Development Fund Companies.     Under the supervision of the Tax Incentive Programs Director and/or Deputy Director, the 420-c/Article XI Analyst will perform complex technical, administrative and analytical work in managing the programs.  Responsibilities include, but are not limited to:    Review and verify completeness of exemption applications and the accuracy of certificates for compliance with applicable program law, policy, procedures and rules;    Coordinating review with the development team, finance sources, and agency loan staff and providing research support, training, supervision, and troubleshooting for Division and agency staff to resolve program issues;    Draft submissions for City Council approval of Article XI tax exemptions;    Review and analyze project-specific underwriting analyses for the Article XI and 420-c programs;    With the assistance of the TIP Director and Deputy Director, interpret applicable laws and regulations for tax programs;     Provide technical assistance in the interpretation of program requirements to the agency staff and the public;     Create and maintain program indicators, statistics, and program revenue collections; and     Perform analytical and other special projects identified by the unit director.

job_description: **  CIVIL SERVICE TITLE: ASSOCIATE CORRECTIONAL COUNSELOR    The Division of Preventive and Primary Care/Bureau of Correctional Health Services/Transitional Health Care Coordination has 3 vacancies for Associate Correctional Counselor. Transitional Health Coordination is responsible for overseeing health education programs and coordinating community collaborations to facilitate linkages to health care for those leaving City jails with chronic health conditions such as hypertension, diabetes and asthma as well as STDs and HIV/AIDS. Transitional Health Care Coordination services are integrated with other programs in the Bureau of Correctional Health Services and the Bureau of Primary Care Access and Planning. It also has partnerships with other DOHMH programs, the District Public Health Offices, other City agencies and community-based providersâ€™ throughout the City. In addition, THCC works closely with the jail based health providers to facilitate continuity of care from intake jails to community health care for those in City jails.     The Bureau Correctional Health Servicesâ€™ Transitional Health Care Coordination (THCC) is responsible for overseeing health education programs and coordinating community collaborations to facilitate linkages to health care for those leaving City jails with chronic health conditions such as hypertension, diabetes, and asthma as well as HIV/AIDS and substance use disorders (SUD). The services of THCC are integrated with other programs in the Bureau of Correctional Health Services (CHS) and the Bureau of Primary Care Access & Planning (PCAP).  It also has partnerships with other DOHMH programs, the District Public Health Offices, other City agencies and community-based providers throughout the City. In addition, THCC works closely with the jail based health providers to facilitate continuity of care from intake jails to community health care for those in City jails including those with chronic/communicable health conditions including SUD returning to the communities of greatest health disparities who face multiple social service issues, who are unemployed or under-employed.       Specific Duties and Responsibilities:      â€¢	Providing guidance and support to a team of jail-based correctional counselors to coordinate assignment / tasks and show leadership in identifying community resources and programs appropriate to meet the needs of people returning home after incarceration in the areas of housing, substance use / behavioral health treatment, preventive and primary care.      â€¢	Using motivational interviewing skills and other techniques to assess readiness for change.    â€¢	Conducting  a comprehensive service needs assessment and goal setting with each client.    â€¢	Working alongside CHS medical staff, provide brief interventions, treatment counseling, health education, crisis interventions and other direct services.     â€¢	Overseeing the counselling and documentation, referral and reports process for one or more jail-facility.    â€¢	 Providing direct counselling to clients with SUD, HIV/AIDS and other chronically related health conditions.     â€¢	 Evaluating and making recommendations regarding interview process with clients seen by correctional counselors / patient care coordinators.     â€¢	Conducting in-service training to team and other of community-based providers.     â€¢	Coordinating and scheduling assignments for jail-based team.     â€¢	Providing administrative coverage in the absence of Program Director.    â€¢	Provide brief counselling interventions for substance use disorders.

job_description: DoITT provides for the sustained, efficient and effective delivery of IT services, infrastructure and telecommunications to enhance service delivery to New York City's residents, businesses, employees and visitors. job_description: The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission (TLC) is the agency responsible for licensing and regulating New York City's yellow taxicabs, for-hire vehicles (community-based liveries and black cars), commuter vans, paratransit vehicles, and certain luxury limousines. job_description: ***REVISED***    The NYC Department of Homeless Services seeks an Administrative Staff Analyst NM 3 with superior management skills. A dynamic, experienced, highly motivated and talented individual will serve as the Director of Payroll and Timekeeping. The candidate must possess superior analytical, problem solving, and creative thinking abilities to act as the Director of Payroll and Timekeeping. Reporting directly to the Assistant Commissioner for Human Resources, the Director of Payroll/Timekeeping will manage the daily operations of professional, technical and clerical staff performing functions which include payroll, timekeeping, audit, office management, processing operations, customer service and records management.    With latitude for independent judgment and decision-making, the Director will ensure that the agency is in full compliance with the standards governing payroll and timekeeping operations.  The Director will maximize the agencyâ€™s use of the CityTime database, NYC Automated Personnel System (NYCAPS), Payroll Management System (PMS), and the Citywide Human Resources Management System (CHRMS).  Through management of the Payroll Unit, the Director will oversee the distribution of the bi-weekly payroll, direct deposits of funds, receipts to employees, the payment of annuities, supper money, the reimbursement of certain professional fees, the processing of deductions for Individual Retirement Accounts, the College Savings Program, WageWorks, Savings Bonds and the Combined Municipal Campaign.  Through management of the Timekeeping Unit, the Director will oversee the preparation and input of timekeeping data into PMS, authorize additions, deletions and changes. The Director will also ensure adherence to Citywide Time and Leave policies, oversee the calculation of terminal pay, overtime, and the adjustment and payout of final leave balances for non-managerial employees.

job_description: DFTA-002-Active Aging:  Identifies and Coordinates with Community:  Conducts outreach within the NYCHA community seeking grandparents/elderly relatives caring for children under the age of 18.  Provides case assistance/advocacy and referrals as needed.  Represents the unit in community, tenant and other related meetings.  Will co-facilitate support group and trainings.  Participates in special projects as needed (Grandparent's Day and summer events).    DFTA-003-Emergency Preparedness:  Under the direct supervision of Assistant Commissioner:  Learn emergency preparedness information to assist in giving at minimum one presentation per week to community partners and staff.  Assist in review of emergency preparedness plans including analyzing, writing up findings and making recommended improvements.  Assist in review and updating emergency plan for DFTA.  Track DFTA staff completion of Coastal Storm Plan training.     DFTA-004-BCS Health Promotions:  Keep on Track is a volunteer run blood pressure monitoring program that trains volunteers to take blood pressure readings using a digital monitor.  Keep on Track helps seniors control existing cases of hypertension, and also has identified cases of this silent killer.  The program is administered via DFTA's community partners.  The program design includes monthly/bi-weekly monitoring sessions where participants' blood pressure is monitored and recorded.  Education and medication compliance as defined by program protocols is also stressed with participants.  This intern would be responsible for assessing the status of Keep on Track programs, interviewing possible volunteers for the program, providing appropriate training for the volunteers and implementing the Dashboard, and Internet based personal health record developed by the NYC Department of Health.  The intern would be working with existing programs in neighborhood centers, naturally occurring retirement communities and innovative senior centers in NYC, as well as developing new sites from among this group.  This would be accomplished through one-on one and group meetings with the volunteers and potential volunteers.  The intern's main purpose would be first to gauge the effectiveness/relevancy of the existing program overall; and second to address/remedy any needs/deficiencies of Keep on Track through in-service training and/or an infusion of new volunteers.    DFTA-005-Research:  The intern will be involved in a number of projects over the summer.  The primary project will be to assist in a mental health grant funded project, SMART-MH.  The intern will assist in interviewing older adults to identify their social service and mental health needs.  In addition, the intern will analyze data generated in the field and produce reports as required through the grant.  General responsibilities will involve data collection through interviews, data entry, and data analysis.    DFTA-006-Program Development:  The graduate intern will be assisting on several projects.  The intern will be assisting on the implementation of NY Connects in NYC, a `no wrong door' approach to providing information and assistance to individuals and caregivers with long term care needs, about long term care and support services.  The intern will assist staff in researching and analyzing effective program models, conducting interviews and participating in educational forums and outreach efforts.  The intern may be participating in several other division projects using similar skills sets.    DFTA-007-Planning - Planning Analyst:  The Planning and Policy Analysis Unit seeks a motivated, organized and detail-oriented individual with good quantitative skills to serve as the Planning Intern. The Planning Intern (PI) will work closely with the Unit's Director and Policy Analysts to help enter and analyze data collected from the entire Agency in order to assure the efficient and timely production and delivery of reports to the agency's senior management. job_description: DoITT provides for the sustained, efficient and effective delivery of IT services, infrastructure and telecommunications to enhance service delivery to New York City's residents, businesses, employees and visitors. As the City's technology leader, DoITT is responsible for maintaining the foundational IT infrastructure and systems that touch every aspect of City life from public safety to human services, from education to economic development crossing the full spectrum of governmental operations.    The successful candidate will serve as a Senior Radio System Network Engineer reporting to the IT Services division within the Wireless Technologies unit. Responsibilities will include: Oversee Radio System RF measurements and performance testing including spectral studies on VHF to Microwave frequencies; provide citywide communications drill support which includes driving a Command Vehicle; oversee field assignments including non-tower climbing installations of antennas (at roof-tops), cabling, equipment and associated hardware; utilize various engineering software suites such as link planners, IMD calculators, coverage modeling programs; review field and vendor data and conclude via structured reports to management; configuration of RF and IP equipment including but not limited to Radio repeaters, L2/L3 IP Switches, Routers, Firewalls, subscriber units and radio system related VPN and SNMP designs; technical documentation creation in form of drawings and diagrams for each engineering effort; Engineering/Quality reviews of RF and IP Wireless networks; and supervise special projects and initiatives as assigned.
minimum_qual_requirements: (1) A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college, including or supplemented by twenty-four (24) semester credits in computer science or a related computer field and one (1) year of satisfactory fulltime computer software experience in computer systems development and analysis, applications programming, database administration, systems programming or data communications; or  (2) A four year high school diploma or its educational equivalent and five (5) years of full-time satisfactory computer software experience as described in â€œ1â€ above; or  (3) A satisfactory combination of education and experience that is equivalent to ''1'' or ''2'' above. College education may be substituted for up to two years of the required experience in ''2'' above on the basis that sixty (60) semester credits from an accredited college is equated to one year of experience. In addition, twenty-four (24) semester credits from an accredited college or graduate school in computer science or a related field, or a certificate of at least 625 hours in computer programming from an accredited technical school (post high school), may be substituted for one year of experience. However, all candidates who attempt to qualify under option â€œ3â€ must have at least a four year high school diploma or its educational equivalent and at least two years of satisfactory full-time computer software experience as described in â€œ1â€ above.    To receive credit, all college credits in computer science or a related computer field and/or the certificate in computer programming must be listed in Section A.6 on page 2 of the Education and Experience Test Paper.    Some examples of unacceptable experience are: End users of a computer system, program or software package; experience in the areas of computer technical support, computer operations; data entry/data retrieval; pure quality assurance (QA) auditing and   analysis; hardware installation; help desk; teaching; telecommunications; experience in productivity software products (e.g. word processing, spreadsheet, presentation, and database software, etc.); superficial use of preprogrammed software without   complex programming, design and implementation.
preferred_skills: The preferred candidate should possess the following: A Bachelors Degree in Electrical Engineering or Technology as well 5+ yearsâ€™ experience in Radio Frequency technology, specifically related to: Wireless communications (voice & data), and associated applications; specific knowledge of the New York City geographical environment is preferred; however, similar experience in other large metropolitan cities will be considered; demonstrable knowledge of wireless communications industry trends, service providers and state of the art technologies; quality assurance expertise in large, integrated RF implementations; experience in the integration and planning for radio communications, IP/Wireless designs and associated infrastructure (antennae, receiving and transmitting sites, wired and wireless backhaul, spectrum allocation, L2/3 switches, Routers, Firewalls etc); ability to support rapid tactical deployments including on-scene configurations of Point-to-Point links, LMR repeat and patching systems and interfacing equipment, microwave, UHF, and VHF equipment and all hardware and software related to radio communications and wireless networks; experience in large-scale implementations involving multiple technologies; experience in problem solving, process improvements, and re-engineering methodologies; strong communication, presentation and facilitation skills required; well versed in FCC rules and regulations; organized, creative, flexible, and demonstrate the ability to handle multiple tasks simultaneously under tight deadlines; proficient in the use of Microsoft network operating systems, Excel, Access and project planning software. FCC Commercial licenses and IT certifications are not required but are a plus.  Possession of a Class B CDL Motor Vehicle Driverâ€™s License is preferred.

business_title_phonetic: Research Analyst,  Bureau of Vital Statistics
job_description: With an annual budget of $1.6 billion and more than 6,000 employees throughout the five boroughs, we're one of the largest public health agencies in the world, serving more than 8 million New Yorkers from diverse ethnic and cultural backgrounds. With over 200 years of leadership in the field, we're also one of our nation's oldest public health agencies. The challenges we face range from obesity, diabetes and heart disease to HIV/AIDS, tobacco addiction and substance abuse, and the threat of bioterrorism. We're tackling these issues with innovative policies and programs and getting exceptional results, but our work is never finished. The breadth of our innovative programs provides the widest range of choices for every member of our team.    This is an opportunity for a highly motivated individual to contribute to the data analyses and research activities using vital statistics and other data. Under the unit directorâ€™s supervision, the analyst will:    â€¢	Conduct statistical analyses of birth, death, and other vital events applying standard analytical tools to address the research questions posed.    â€¢	Prioritize and completing internal and external vital statistics data requests as assigned.    â€¢	Produce Annual Summary of Vital Statistics data tables and figures in collaboration with Quality Improvement Unit and Data Use Unit.    â€¢	Produce routine quarterly, monthly, weekly reports.    â€¢	Support internal or external colleagues on data provision and analysis.    â€¢	Draw data for DOHMH programs.    â€¢	Provide consultation or guidance to DOHMH and external data requesters with statistical methods and data interpretations.    â€¢	Perform analyses for reports and peer-review papers, to share these data with wider audience.    â€¢	Other tasks assigned.
minimum_qual_requirements: 1.  For Assignment Level I (only physical, biological and environmental sciences and public health) A master's degree from an accredited college or university with a specialization in an appropriate field of physical, biological or environmental science or in public health. A doctorate degree from an accredited college or university with specialization in an appropriate field of physical, biological, environmental or social science and one year of full-time experience in a responsible supervisory, administrative or research capacity in the appropriate field of specialization; or  2. However, all candidates must have at least a master's degree in an appropriate field of specialization and at least two years of experience described in ''2'' above. Two years as a City Research Scientist Level I can be substituted for the experience required in ''1'' and ''2'' above.    NOTE:  Probationary Period  Appointments to this position are subject to a minimum probationary period of one year.
preferred_skills: The candidate will have academic training in public health, statistics, including applied epidemiology. Strong written and verbal communication skills are required. Extensive experience using SAS and experience using Microsoft Office, Excel, Access, and PowerPoint are also required. The candidate should be a self-starter with strong initiative and sound judgment, who is able to work both independently and in a team to analyze data, provide written interpretations of both statistical analyses results and methods. The preferable candidate will have experience presenting results to expert audiences, such as national public health conferences and peer reviewed manuscripts. The preferable candidate will also have knowledge and experience with the electronic death registration systems, the cause of death coding system within the International Classifications of Diseases (ICD) framework, and experience with large administrative datasets.

job_description: Reporting to the Deputy  Director, the Project Manager is responsible for delivering capital construction projects that meet user needs on-time, within budget and at the appropriate quality level. The Project Manager will supervise, coordinate and monitor all in-house and/or outsourced architectural, engineering and construction management personnel to meet project needs and goals. The selected candidate will focus on successful project delivery utilizing the support systems and resources made available by NYCHA. The candidate will be expected to render all project management decisions, report on progress through the automated project management system and notify the Deputy Director and others when problems arise that require senior management intervention. Responsibilities include, but are not limited to the following:    1.  Create project/construction schedules; serve as the single point of accountability from inception to completion for all capital projects in portfolio.  2.  Coordinate and supervise staff activities to ensure adherence to performance schedules, compliance with design criteria, satisfaction of end-user needs, and quality and thoroughness of design as appropriate for the project.  3.  Monitor budget status of projects during the design phase to ensure design progress is in accordance with budget and take corrective action as required.  4.  Review design structures and examine plans for the construction, alteration or repair of buildings. Review and coordinate pre-bid estimates; evaluate bid proposals; research bidder qualifications and compliance with bid requirements; meet with bidders as necessary; recommend contractors for award of bid contract.  5.  Resolve issues during the design process; examine design review comments from all project stakeholders and ensure they are adequately addressed in future design document revisions.  6.  Ensure staff obtain required approvals during the design and construction phase and maintain appropriate project records. Ensure final project deliverables, including design plans, cost estimates and completed construction projects; address the project goals identified in Project Charters.  7.  Serve as day-to-day management contact with the Construction Manager or Capital Projects field staff monitoring the project ensuring on-time and on-budget performance.  8.  Coordinate staff activities to ensure adequate on-site coverage of projects. Visit construction sites regularly to ensure project objectives are achieved.  9.  Review Requests for Information (RFIs), Submittals (shop drawings, material samples, etc.), contractor or other consultants Requests for Payment and/or invoices, Change Orders, Extensions of Time, Schedule of Values, Progress Schedules and other project correspondence, and take appropriate necessary action.  10.  Utilize and update the electronic project management system to maintain accurate and current project records; schedule in P6 for the life cycle of the project; monitor project progress and any issues requiring follow-up through the automated project management system.  11.  Resolve construction, scope and any coordination problems between NYCHA staff, contractors or the outsourced Construction Manager; recommend course of action to DPD if unable to resolve.  12.  Review field inspection reports and ensure transmission of important issues to senior management via the project management system.  13.  Manage timely close out of projects including full documentation of project and payments. Prepare presentations to professional, government, business, or community groups.  14.  Perform related tasks as assigned by the Deputy Director; may perform supervisory duties in the absence of supervisor.

job_description: Under the direction of the Assistant Commissioner for Inclusionary Housing, the Director of Operations develops, implements, and manages all systems and operations of the Inclusionary Housing Division.  The Director is responsible for identifying office systems that facilitate smooth, efficient, and effective operations of the Inclusionary Housing Division.  The Director will be responsible for supporting a team of energetic, thoughtful, and engaged project managers that work together to manage the process for analyzing, negotiating, and closing inclusionary housing transactions, as well as transitioning projects from closing to asset management and archiving project documents.  The Directorâ€™s role is to be a proactive problem solver and work collaboratively with staff and other HPD offices to develop solutions to create a collaborative and productive Inclusionary Housing Division.    The goal of the Inclusionary Housing Division is to ensure that HPD investments and programs are leveraging and incentivizing other public and private investments to achieve broader community objectives that strengthen the social, economic, and physical health of neighborhoods.  A core objective is to create affordable and accessible housing opportunities in diverse and equitable neighborhoods citywide.      Selected duties of the Director of Operations for Inclusionary Housing include developing and coordinating the Divisionâ€™s processes to create efficiency, coordinating the Divisionâ€™s response to press and other stakeholder inquiries for statistical data, ongoing analysis of project management, tracking and archival systems, as well as archiving transactional documents and transitioning them to other relevant HPD divisions.

job_description: The NYC Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) protects public health and the environment by supplying clean drinking water, collecting and treating wastewater, and reducing air, noise, and hazardous materials pollution. DEP is the largest combined municipal water and wastewater utility in the country, with nearly 6,000 employees. We deliver 1.1 billion gallons of high quality drinking water per day to 8.3 million New York City residents and more than 1 million people in Upstate New York, and we collect and treat an average of 1.3 billion gallons of wastewater per day.    The DEP is seeking a Project Manager who will work in the Bureau of Environmental Planning and Analysis and, under direct supervision, receive training in and, with latitude for the exercise of independent judgment, perform beginning level scientific and applied research and analysis in environmental science including but not limited to conducting City Environmental Quality Review (CEQR) Environmental Assessment Statements, Environmental Impact Statements, and technical air and noise studies. The selected candidate may prepare analyses and studies in support of for environmental reviews for DEPâ€™s water supply, watershed protection, air quality and noise related projects.  In addition, the selected candidate may also provide input on capital projects during development and design, participate in planning efforts and studies, and assist in the development of programs to address regulatory requirements.
minimum_qual_requirements: 1.  For Assignment Level I (only physical, biological and environmental sciences and public health) A master's degree from an accredited college or university with a specialization in an appropriate field of physical, biological or environmental science or in public health.  To be appointed to Assignment Level II and above, candidates must have:  1. A doctorate degree from an accredited college or university with specialization in an appropriate field of physical, biological, environmental or social science and one year of full-time experience in a responsible supervisory, administrative or research capacity in the appropriate field of specialization; or  2. Two years as a City Research Scientist Level I can be substituted for the experience required in ''1'' and ''2'' above. job_description: The Law Department is now accepting applications for the position of Assistant Corporation Counsel in the Appeals Division. The Appeals Division represents the City of New York, its agencies, and its officers and employees in appellate litigation on a diverse range of constitutional, statutory, and common law issues. An attorney in this Division should expect to brief and argue a substantial caseload of appeals before the state and federal appellate courts.
minimum_qual_requirements: Applicants must have graduated from an ABA accredited law school or be scheduled to graduate in May or June 2015. Prior appellate experience, including clerkship experience, is preferred but not required.

job_description: The Bureau of School Health (BSH) is a joint program between the Department of Education and the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene which is responsible for promoting the health of the 1.3 million school children enrolled in approximately 1,800 public and non-public schools in New York City. Services to students include case management of chronic health problems, preventive health screening, urgent care, medication administration, preventive counseling, reproductive health services, health education referral for care and assurance of ongoing effective treatment. BSH has been the provider of public health services for 100 years.
